channel.title: Read Rust - Tools and Applications
channel.description: Tools and Applications posts on Read Rust

item.title: Introducing cargo-instruments: zero-hassle profiling on macOS
item.description: cargo-instruments (github) is a cargo plugin that makes it easy to profile rust binaries on macOS. tl;dr: cargo-instruments is a shim between cargo and Xcode's very powerful dtrace-backed diagnostic suite, Instruments. Out of the box, this lets you track cpu / thread usage, allocations, context switches, and a bunch of other stuff.
item.dc:creator: cmyr

item.title: ActivityWatch automatic time-tracking software switches to Rust
item.description: While Python is a great language to quickly build new features in, itâ€™s not great for performance or deploying to multiple platforms (especially Android). So @johan-bjareholt took on the tremendous task of reimplementing aw-server in the highly performant and secure programming language Rust. Since Rust compiles to Android we have built a library for use on Android, letting us avoid reimplement all of ActivityWatch to Android devices specifically (and vastly decreases the time to port future features like sync to Android).
item.dc:creator: Erik BjÃ¤reholt

item.title: Remote Development and Debugging of Rust with CLion
item.description: Most in our team use CLion for Rust development which is especially great for local debugging, alas it is not free. Since we are developing a blockchain it requires careful orchestration of the nodes running on separate machines, and occasionally we need to debug some corner case on a remotely running node. CLion and other JetBrains products have great support of the remote development and debugging. However, unfortunately, Rust is not a primary language of CLion which makes configuration tricky. In this post we walk through the configuration of CLion for remote Rust development and debugging.
item.dc:creator: Maksym Zavershynskyi

item.title: Building the virtualization stack of the future with rust-vmm
item.description: rust-vmm facilitates sharing core virtualization components between Rust Virtual Machine Monitors.
item.dc:creator: Andreea Florescu

item.title: Torchbear - a fast and complete interpreter for the new Speakeasy langauge
item.description: Torchbear is a new programming environment currently available for Windows, Android, MacOS, and Linux. With it, you get Rust's great library ecosystem, but you don't need to recompile with each change to how you use those libraries. Since you express your domain logic in a higher level scripting language and your system logic in Rust's language, you get the best of both worlds!
item.dc:creator: Mitchell Tannenbaum

item.title: Forge: A scripting language for Rust gamedev inspired by JS, Rust and Python
item.description: Forge is a dynamically-typed language written in Rust. It is inspired by JavaScript, Rust, Python and Rhai. In the future, you'll be able to use Forge as a general-purpose lightweight scripting language in your applications.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barretto

item.title: New cargo subcommand: sync-readme
item.description: cargo sync-readme synchronizes your README (the file specified by the readme key in your Cargo.toml, or just README.md by default) with the entrypoint of your library or binary crate (by default, lib.rs or main.rs, or what is defined at the path key in your manifest).
item.dc:creator: Dimitri Sabadie

item.title: Part 4: Line IDs in toy version control system, oji
item.description: Iâ€™ve written quite a bit about the theory of patches and merging, but nothing yet about how to actually implement anything efficiently. That will be the subject of this post, and probably some future posts too.
item.dc:creator: Joe Neeman

item.title: git req | switch branches, not context
item.description: Check out git branches by their pull (or merge) request ID
item.dc:creator: Aru Sahni

item.title: Part 3: Graggles can have cycles
item.description:
Almost two years ago, I promised a series of three posts about version control. The first two (here and here) introduced a new (at the time) framework for version control. The third post, which I never finished, was going to talk about the datastructures and algorithms used in pijul, a version control system built around that new framework. The problem is that pijul is a complex piece of software, and so I had lots of trouble wrapping my head around it.
Two years later, Iâ€™m finally ready to continue with this series of posts (but having learned from my earlier mistakes, Iâ€™m not going to predict the total number of posts ahead of time). In the meantime, Iâ€™ve written my own toy version control system (VCS) to help me understand whatâ€™s going on. Itâ€™s called ojo, and itâ€™s extremely primitive: to start with, it can only track a single file. However, it is (just barely) sophisticated enough to demonstrate the important ideas. Iâ€™m also doing my best to make the code is clear and well-documented.
item.dc:creator: Joe Neeman

item.title: Rust Lifetime Visualization Ideas
item.description: Many people have had the idea that there should be a way to visualize lifetimes in Rust. Indeed, the Rust Book used to include ASCII diagrams of lifetimes in some code examples. When fighting the borrow checker, it would be great if the IDE or editor could automatically provide a visualization of the lifetimes in your code.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Walker

item.title: Mod player in Rust - part 4. Finally some music
item.description: In this post we will finally have some music. I will spend some time discussing how the Amiga sound hardware worked. The original mod file format and how it is played back is intimately linked with the Amiga hardware.
item.dc:creator: Jani Peltonen

item.title: syswall: a firewall for syscalls
item.description: A while back I started thinking about software and how it does what it does. Perhaps even more importantly, I started thinking about how we can know what software does, without relying on the software's marketing pitch.
item.dc:creator: Simon Pugnet

item.title: Shipping Rust Binaries with GoReleaser
item.description: Although GoReleaser supports building just Go projects, it does so much more in the packaging and distribution department that it is extremely hard to ignore.
item.dc:creator: Dotan Nahum

item.title: MonkeyType: type inference for transpiling Python to Rust
item.description: In my previous post about Python to Rust transpiler Iâ€™ve said, that one of the biggest problems is absence of types in python and inability to infer them for functions. But it turns out there is a solution to this problem. Guys from Instagram have developed an incredible tool for runtime type inference called MonkeyType. It monitors what types functions accept and return while running a program. This approach works quite nicely so I want to share with you how itâ€™s done.
item.dc:creator: Julian Konchunas

item.title: Introducing swc (speedy web compiler) 1.0
item.description: swc(speedy web compiler) is a super-fast javascript to javascript compiler. It can transpile typescript / jsx / ecmascript 2019 to browser-compatible javascript. It's 16x - 20x faster than babel even on single-core synchronous benchmark. Note that actual performance gap is larger because swc works on worker thread while babel works on event loop thread.
item.dc:creator: DongYoon Kang

item.title: Notion: the hassle-free JavaScript toolchain manager
item.description:
Reliable: Ensure everyone in your project uses an identical dev environment, from the Node version to your preferred package manager.
Universal: Enjoy the same command-line experience in every shell and every major operating system.
Fast: Notion is implemented in Rust and deployed as a static executable for maximum performance.
item.dc:creator: LinkedIn Engineering

item.title: A Python Interpreter written in Rust
item.description: Goals: Full Python-3 environment entirely in Rust (not CPython bindings). A clean implementation without compatibility hacks
item.dc:creator: RustPython

item.title: Hello, sandboxfs 0.1.0
item.description:
I am pleased to announce that the first release of sandboxfs, 0.1.0, is finally here! You can download the sources and prebuilt binaries from the 0.1.0 release page and you can read the installation instructions for more details.
The journey to this first release has been a long one. sandboxfs was first conceived over two years ago, was first announced in August 2017, showed its first promising results in April 2018, and has been undergoing a rewrite from Go to Rust.
item.dc:creator: Julio Merino

item.title: Mod player in Rust - part 3. Audio and threads
item.description: I finished my last post with having a fully parsed mod file in memory and ready to be played. By the end of this post I want to get the code into a state where the main thread lets the user pick instruments from the mod file and play them back on the audio thread.
item.dc:creator: Jani Peltonen

item.title: A detailed guide to writing your first Neovim plugin in Rust
item.description: I recently wrote a plugin in Rust to control the Spotify desktop app for MacOS and find lyrics from within Neovim and found it to be a neat experience overall, and thatâ€™s coming from someone who isnâ€™t a Rust expert. This post is a summary of all the research and discovery that happened during that process.
item.dc:creator: Srishan Bhattarai

item.title: Rust powered CLI apk decompiler
item.description: Lately Iâ€™ve been needing to reverse engineer some apks and Iâ€™ve been manually using some third-party tools to do so. But, how could we speed up the process? A little bit of Rust can be very helpful!
item.dc:creator: Roberto Huertas

item.title: Packaging a game for Windows, Mac, and Linux with Rust.
item.description: Building a cross platform game for desktop operating systems in Rust is fairly doable without needing much platform specific code. Glutin is a Rust alternative to SDL for handling window creation & input. GFX handles most of the graphics API abstraction for you. You still write the shaders, but I was able to just use OpenGL and get it working on Windows 10, MacOS, and Ubuntu.
item.dc:creator: Aaron McLeod

item.title: Medic: A Rust CLI that checks the passwords of a KeePass database
item.description:
After the recent breach, I was curious to check my passwords against the list, but Iâ€™m a bit paranoid, so, rather than paste my passwords into the Have I Been Pwned website, I wanted to download the big text file and check my passwords against it offline, nice and safely.
I use a password manager called KeePassXC, so all of my passwords are stored in an encrypted file â€“ a KeePass database â€“ and I use a program called KeePassXC, a free and open-source password manager, to manage them (I wrote a beginnerâ€™s user guide to KeePassXC a while back if youâ€™re interested!). So ideally, to check my passwords against the big list, Iâ€™d have a tool that checks all the passwords in a given KeePass database against the entire HaveIBeenPwned list of passwords, preferably against the downloaded file (i.e. â€œofflineâ€), rather than the API. In other words something similar to 1Passwordâ€™s Watchtower feature, but preferably offline.
After poking around a bit I decided to write it myself in Rust, with this script and this crate as useful references. Medic is a Rust CLI that can perform a variety of â€œhealthâ€ checks on a KeePass database.
item.dc:creator: Sam Schlinkert

item.title: Mod player in Rust - part 2
item.description: My last article finished with reading the pattern tables from the mode files. In this post I want to finish parsing the entire file so we can move onto playing it. First we need to work out where the pattern data is and how long it is.
item.dc:creator: Jani Peltonen

item.title: Using Rust for creating Ubuntu Touch apps
item.description: This post aims to give you a small introduction to using the Rust programming language for writing apps for Ubuntu touch.
item.dc:creator: Tim SÃ¼berkrÃ¼b

item.title: Mod player in Rust - part 1
item.description: For my next Rust project I want to try something a bit more challenging than the Sudoku solver. I want to write a mod player in Rust.
item.dc:creator: Jani Peltonen

item.title: A Very Relatable Database: Part 1
item.description:
I like to find ways to fill up my free time over winter breaks. Since Iâ€™m not in school for a month, I usually take the time to do some self-study on a topic I find interesting. This past month, it was building a database. Unfortunately, I had only a casual understanding of how a database actually works under the hood, and no idea how to get started. Additionally, I decided to write the database in Rust, since I knew there would be complicated management of data, and I wanted to avoid headaches involving invalid data. Finally, rustâ€™s static garbage collector meant I wouldnâ€™t have to rely on a runtime to guarantee this.
That was a month ago. While Iâ€™m not too far along (mostly due to being busier than expected during the break), I still have things I think are worth sharing.
item.dc:creator: Nate Lincoln

item.title: sharkdp/hexyl: A command-line hex viewer
item.description: hexyl is a simple hex viewer for the terminal. It uses a colored output to distinguish different categories of bytes (NULL bytes, printable ASCII characters, ASCII whitespace characters, other ASCII characters and non-ASCII).
item.dc:creator: David Peter

item.title: PyOxidizer: Make distributable Python applications using Rust
item.description: PyOxidizer is a collection of Rust crates that facilitate building libraries and binaries containing Python interpreters. PyOxidizer is capable of producing a single file executable - with all dependencies statically linked and all resources (like .pyc files) embedded in the executable.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Szorc

item.title: I made MPD index SoundCloud, here's how I did it
item.description:
The usual process of playing something on our music server is a bit cumbersome: I have to browse SoundCloud, download a track that seems interesting, upload it to the music server, let MPD index it, and then play it.
To make my life easier, I wanted to leverage Linuxâ€™s FUSE interface to expose the audio on SoundCloud as a bunch of files in a folder which MPD could then index and play from. I could have taken a couple of other approaches such as swapping MPD with Mopidy, an MPD-compatible music player with SoundCloud support, or a scraper that periodically downloads the latest audio from my feed. And while these alternatives were probably easier to implement, I went for the FUSE driver because I thought it was cool.
item.dc:creator: polyfloyd

item.title: Debugging Rust with VSCode on FreeBSD
item.description: The following is a set of notes for installing VSCode on FreeBSD and getting a debugger up and running in a step by step guide. I thought I would share them in a full post as having a full IDE with syntax and error highlighting along with detailed in-context explanations has been really useful as I get to grips with Rust.
item.dc:creator: Anton Whalley

item.title: Tools in the 2018 edition
item.description: In this blog post I'll cover Clippy and Rustfmt â€“ two tools that have been around for a few years and are now stable and ready for general use. I'll also cover IDE support â€“ a key workflow for many users which is now much better supported. I'll start by talking about Rustfix, a new tool which was central to our edition migration plans.
item.dc:creator: The Dev-tools team

item.title: Rust Analyzer in 2018 and 2019
item.description:
Hi! I am Aleksey Kladov (aka @matklad). In the past, I've worked at Jet Brains where I've helped to create the IntelliJ Rust plug-in, and now I am a part of the Ferrous Systems team.
I've spent a significant amount of the last year experimenting with various approaches to make the Rust IDE story better. The culmination of my experiments is the rust-analyzer project â€“ an experimental Rust compiler frontend, targeting the IDE/Language Server Protocol use case.
item.dc:creator: Aleksey Kladov

item.title: cargo-inspect: A Little Tool for Exploring Rust Internals
item.description: Rust allows for a lot of syntactic sugar, that makes it a pleasure to write. It is sometimes hard, however, to look behind the curtain and see what the compiler is really doing with our code. I wondered if there was a tool, which revealed what Rust was doing behind the curtains.
item.dc:creator: Matthias Endler

item.title: Build Your Own Shell using Rust
item.description: This is a tutorial on building your own shell using Rust, in the spirit of the build-your-own-x list. Creating a shell is a great way to understand how the shell, terminal emulator, and OS work together.
item.dc:creator: Josh Mcguigan

item.title: Qt applications with Cargo
item.description: This blog shows how Qt applications can be built with Cargo. The goal is to make compiling them as simple as installing Qt and running cargo build.
item.dc:creator: Jos van den Oever

item.title: korq: Kubernetes Dynamic Log Tailing Utility
item.description: Kâˆ…RQ is used for tailing pod logs concurrently and following groups at once. It was basically a need to follow logs during deployment and see how instances behave during and after deployment. This is the main motive behind Kâˆ…RQ.
item.dc:creator: Mahmut Bulut

item.title: ruplacer: find and replace text in source files
item.description: Today Iâ€™d like to talk about a command-line tool Iâ€™ve been working on. Itâ€™s called ruplacer and as the name suggest, itâ€™s rually cool and written in Rust. Basically, it finds and replaces text in source files.
item.dc:creator: Dimitri Merejkowsky

item.title: Rust Programming with Dynamsoft Barcode Reader
item.description: A few days ago, I accepted a new challenge of creating a simple command line barcode reader using Rust and Dynamsoft Barcode Reader SDK. Rust is a system programming language similar to C++. The learning process did not go through smoothly as I expected. It is not as easy as learning other high-level programming languages such as Java and Python. In this article, I share my experience of learning and using Rust.
item.dc:creator: Xiao Ling

item.title: imag: Call for Participation (1)
item.description:
This is the first call for participation for the imag project. I have no experience writing such calls for participation, so please bear with me!
Right now, the imag ecosystem has some tools available which are already usable and in rather good shape. There is a contact manager, a diary and a notes tool, a habit tracker and a time tracker are there as well, though those are not extensively tested by now.
item.dc:creator: imag

item.title: Remacs continues to improve
item.description: As you doubtless know, Emacs has an embedded Lisp environment that provides a large number of intersting Lisp functions that the user can call. Many of these are implemented in C for speed, and we've been rewriting them in Rust. So far we've ported 394 individual Lisp functions from C to Rust, of which 207 were ported in this last year. This is about a third of the total, as you can see by this graph. We've actually completely ported several whole C files now.
item.dc:creator: db48x

item.title: Running Little Rust Snippets with Runner
item.description: runner is mostly a clever wrapper around normal Cargo operations. runner acts like an interpreter. There is no forced directory structure, just source. But itâ€™s just using rustc under the hood in the most direct way possible.
item.dc:creator: Steve Donovan

item.title: Hegemon: A modular system monitor written in Rust
item.description: Hegemon is a work-in-progress modular system monitor written in safe Rust. Currently, it has the following features: Monitor CPU and memory usage, temperatures, and fan speeds; expand any data stream to reveal a more detailed graph and additional information, adjustable update interval.
item.dc:creator: Philipp Emanuel Weidmann

item.title: Alacritty now supports scrollback
item.description: Alacritty, the OpenGL terminal emulator written in Rust, now supports scrollback! Performance has improved, and we've got benchmarks to share.
item.dc:creator: Joe Wilm

item.title: A Sudoku Solver & Generator ðŸ”¢
item.description: For a small side project Iâ€™m working on, Iâ€™m using a Sudoku puzzle solver and puzzle generator that Iâ€™ve written in Rust. The experience was fun, so I thought Iâ€™d write up a little bit about the algorithm Iâ€™ve used and some interesting stats about how it performs.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Levick

item.title: Browsing your mail with Rust and Qt
item.description: Letâ€™s write a mail viewer with Rust and Qt. This is another blog about Rust Qt Binding Generator, the project that lets you add a Qt GUI to your Rust code, or if you will, add Rust to your Qt program.
item.dc:creator: Jos van den Oever

item.title: TOTP generator with account handling for multiple tokens
item.description: a totp generator I wrote a while ago in C++ but now itâ€™s in rust. It can generate a token and save it into an account file that is AES encrypted. The password is never saved, so itâ€™s secure enough to use it. One of itâ€™s properties it will have over the c++ implementation is itâ€™s safe, it uses a proper IV and once Iâ€™m done, it will also support encryption via PGP.
item.dc:creator: Gergely Brautigam

item.title: Rust at Datalust
item.description: At Datalust we build a log server called Seq. It's really a database, written in C#, with its own SQL-based query language, that's specifically designed for storing and querying structured log data. In the past, Seq has managed log event storage through ESENT, which is a storage technology baked into Windows. For our cross-platform Seq 5 release weâ€™ve built a storage engine called Flare in the Rust programming language to replace our usage of ESENT.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Mannix

item.title: Password Generation in Ruby and Rust
item.description: Writing the same password generator in two different languages to learn more Rust.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Hurst

item.title: IntelliJ Rust features. Entry one: Macros
item.description: In this series of short blog posts, we are going to take a closer look at the key Rust related features present in JetBrains IDEs through our corresponding plugin.
item.dc:creator: Kirill Malich

item.title: C2rust - A bridge to C
item.description: The c2rust project exists to help bridge the fact that there is a lot of valuable software written in C and that there have been great strides in making safer and more-reliable programming languages since C was designed. Rust offers many modern improvements for C while still preserving the low-level control that makes it attractive. Beyond that, Rust provides new abstraction capabilities like parametricity, type-traits, methods, a module system, thread-safety, and more.
item.dc:creator: Eric Mertens

item.title: Incremental Parsing in Amp
item.description: With the latest release of Amp (text editor), syntax highlighting has been overhauled. This post dives into the performance-related redesign that has landed with v0.5.
item.dc:creator: Jordan MacDonald

item.title: Journey into Gentoo eclass
item.description: I spent some days writing a portage eclass for Gentoo. I want to share my experience.
item.dc:creator: gibix

item.title: Kickstart - a fast and simple project template bootstrapper
item.description: Ever had some code base that you regularly use to start a new project? Until now, you've probably lost some time refactoring everything to fill out the right project name, title etc. A few tools already exist but either you're lost in feature bloating hell or you're fighting to configure everything in most cases. The following tool is an early-developement, rust-based, template tool made to be more versatile that its closest python counter-part, cookiecutter.
item.dc:creator: Artemis

item.title: Easily Analyzing Your S3 Buckets
item.description: mazon S3 is a storage solution used by pretty much everyone these days. Due to this there are naturally a bunch of tools for doing almost everything you can think of with S3. This post is about a tool I wrote to retrieve metadata about S3 buckets. If you don't care for the post, feel free to skip straight to the repo.
item.dc:creator: Isaac Whitfield

item.title: Gutenberg 0.4.0: custom taxonomies, image processing and more
item.description: Gutenberg 0.4.0 is out with custom taxonomies, image processing, improved shortcodes and more.
item.dc:creator: Vincent Prouillet

item.title: CLion IDE Rust plugin update: language support improvements, new quick-fixes, improved debugger and more
item.description: CLion 2018.2 was released just recently. Along with the release, the Rust plugin has had an update! In this blog post, weâ€™d like to highlight some of the main improvements in the plugin.
item.dc:creator: Anastasia Kazakova

item.title: Why I Ripped The Same CD 300 Times
item.description: The piano arrangement album å¸°ã‚‹ã¹ãåŸŽ by Altneuland was published in 2005. I discovered it in 2008 (probably on YouTube), downloaded the best copy I could find, and filed it away in the TODO list. Recent advances in international parcel forwarding technology let me buy a used copy last year, but when it arrived none of my CD drives could read track #3. This sort of thing is common when buying used CDs, especially if they need to transit a USPS international shipping center. I shelved it and kept on the lookout for another copy, which I located last month. It arrived on Friday, I immediately tried to rip it, and hit the exact same error. This didnâ€™t seem to be an issue of wear or damageâ€¦
item.dc:creator: John Millikin

item.title: Sequoia, a new OpenPGP implementation
item.description: This past fall, three former GnuPG developers began working on a new OpenPGP implementation in Rust called Sequoia. As itâ€™s starting to shape up and become useful, I feel now is a good time to announce the project to the larger Rust community, and hopefully get some feedback before our first release.
item.dc:creator: /u/nwalfield

item.title: Announcing Vagga 0.8.1 â€“ PaulColomiets
item.description: We are excited to announce the next version of vagga, the containerization tool that makes setting up development environments easy and fun. This release brings local overrides for vagga commands, support of ubuntu bionic, better CI support, space reuse between multiple projects, and more.
item.dc:creator: PaulColomiets

item.title: Recommending books (with Rust)
item.description: In this post, weâ€™re going to build a sequence-based recommender system in Rust: a system that accepts a personâ€™s reading history as input, and outputs recommendations on what to read next.
item.dc:creator: Maciej Kula

item.title: Introducing the Routinator 3000
item.description: NLnet Labs is embarking on a new adventure. In the coming months we will be developing an RPKI toolset aimed at making BGP routing more secure. It will consist of three parts: a Certificate Authority package, a Publication Server and Relying Party software. Weâ€™ve chosen to do the development in a modern systems programming language, Rust.
item.dc:creator: Alex Band

item.title: Pax: A fast dev time JavaScript bundler
item.description: Donâ€™t waste time waiting for your bundler to do its thing. Use Pax while youâ€™re developing, and iterate to your heartâ€™s content. Use your super-cool, magical, slow-as-molasses bundler for releases, when you donâ€™t care how long it takes to run.
item.dc:creator: Nathan

item.title: glitchcat â€” Creating CLI apps in Rust is super easy
item.description: glitchcat is a cat-like program with glitch animation.
item.dc:creator: kuviman

item.title: cargo-generate: create a new Rust project from a template
item.description: cargo-generate is a developer tool to help you get up and running quickly with a new Rust project by leveraging a pre-existing git repository as a template.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Williams

item.title: How we built a Visual Studio Code extension for IoT prototyping
item.description: We recently had the opportunity to make a Visual Studio Code extension that needed to communicate with an embedded device. This post explains the architecture we chose to achieve that and the decisions that led to it.
item.dc:creator: Dan Munckton

item.title: Bioyino â€” a distributed, scalable metric aggregator
item.description: So, you collect metrics. So do we. Yep, we also collect them. We can assure you that they are not useless at all, business guys do needâ€¦
item.dc:creator: Sergey N

item.title: Moving from the shell to Rust with commandspec
item.description: Almost every project Iâ€™ve worked on has grown a shell script named â€œbuild.shâ€, and not much later a â€œtest.shâ€ and â€œrun.shâ€. At this point, you have to make a decision as a developer whether your goal is to accidentally reinvent make or if your codebaseâ€™s needs are better met by an executable to manage your workflow.
item.dc:creator: Tim Ryan

item.title: fastcat - A Faster 'cat' Implementation Using Splice
item.description:
Lots of people asked me to write another piece about the internals of well-known Unix commands. Well, actually, nobody asked me, but it makes for a good intro. I'm sure youâ€™ve read the previous parts about yes and ls â€” they are awesome.
Anyway, today we talk about cat, which is used to concatenate files - or, more commonly, abused to print a file's contents to the screen.
item.dc:creator: Matthias Endler

item.title: devtop: Command line parser
item.description: As operator I found that existing tooling fails with large number of unusual devices. If you have server with >100 virtual machines, and each virtual machines have one or more additional disk and a few network interfaces, itâ€™s hard to find which VM cause stress on the server. Normal atop simply couldnâ€™t cope with hundreds of tap/tun interfaces, multitude of block devices, etc. When I found that I have no proper tooling (as an operator) I wrote a shabby tools to do my job: they are calling blktop and ifstop. Both were written dirty and fast, and they does not follow the usual Python conventions (but they work as standalone binaries). They do their job, and normally I would say thatâ€™s enough. But those utilities are simple and have no big complications under the hood, so they are perfect candidates for rewriting in Rust for the sake of writing in Rust (Iâ€™m learning it!). I decide to combine them into a single utility: devtop, which I want to develop properly, according to Rust conventions, and through all aspects of packaging.
item.dc:creator: George Shuklin

item.title: Oxy - A Security Focused Remote Access Tool
item.description: It's like SSH, but more secure, and with cool modern features. It is not an implementation of SSH, it is a new, modern protocol.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Magius

item.title: Finda Websocket Architecture
item.description: Finda lets you search and instantly switch between tabs in browsers like Firefox and Chrome and editors like Sublime Text and Visual Studio Code. It does this by communicating with these programs over local websocket connections. This article describes the design tradeoffs of this system, focusing on Rust implementation details that may be helpful to others building similar systems.
item.dc:creator: Kevin J. Lynagh

item.title: Extreme benchmark feedback using Gitlab CI
item.description: I am quite notorious for exploiting Gitlabâ€™s CI. Ever since I started playing with it at the start of 2016, I tended to make things worse.
item.dc:creator: Ruben De Smet

item.title: Using Rust Code in a C/C++ Project with CMake
item.description:
I am currently working on Wayk Now written in C for the most part. We recently started writing new code for it in Rust which Iâ€™m super excited about.
As we needed a way to integrate this code in our CMake build1, we wrote a set of modules for CMake
item.dc:creator: Sebastien Duquette

item.title: C2Rust Demonstration
item.description: The C2Rust project is being developed by Galois and Immunant. This tool is able to translate most C modules into semantically equivalent Rust code. These modules are intended to be compiled in isolation in order to produce compatible object files. We are developing several tools that help transform the initial Rust sources into idiomatic Rust.
item.dc:creator: Galois and Immunant

item.title: My Emacs Rust IDE
item.description: In this post, I will walk you through configuring an EMACS Rust IDE to get syntax highlighting and code completion for the Rust programming language.
item.dc:creator: Bill Ward

item.title: Nannou open source creative coding framework
item.description: Nannou is an open source creative coding framework built in Rust for artists, hackers, designers and devs to express themselves with simple, fast, reliable, portable code.
item.dc:creator: Mitch, Josh, Keenan & Tom

item.title: What do you think are the most interesting/exciting projects using Rust?
item.description: Last week I tweeted "What do you think are the most interesting/exciting projects using Rust? (No self-promotion :-) )". The response was awesome! Jonathan Turner suggested I write up the responses as a blog post, and here we are.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cameron

item.title: To do a Rust GUI
item.description:
Rust Qt Binding Generator lets you combine Rust code with a Qt1 graphical application. A previous blog shows how to make a simple clock. Itâ€™s a good idea to read that post before reading this more advanced post, because in this post we are getting serious.
This blog post shows how to write a to-do application. The data model is a list of to-do items. The source code for this example is available in the folder examples/todos in the Rust Qt Binding Generator repository.
item.dc:creator: Jos van den Oever

item.title: Fishing in an Abyss: Building a Password Cracker in Rust
item.description: Ahead of this yearâ€™s World Password Day, 1Password â€“ maker of password management software â€“ announced a password cracking challenge. The company ostensibly wanted to find out how hard it would be to crack a three-word passphrase master password on one of their vaults, assuming that the attacker had the derived hash of the passphrase.
item.dc:creator: Sam Schlinkert

item.title: madparts-rs 1.0 release
item.description: Back in Februari 2013 then coworker Romain S. showed me the new trend of programming editors that do continuous compilation while you type, showing you immediate feedback on your code. In parallel I also worked on 3D modeling for my 3D printer using the OpenSCAD program. OpenSCAD works by writing code in its custom language and then have it rendered. I had this idea of combining these two approaches to make an electronics footprint generator. And so the development of the original madparts program started. In August 2016 I had been playing with the then pretty new rust programming language and decided a rewrite in it and simplifying the program even further would be fun to do.
item.dc:creator: Joost Yervante Damad

item.title: An image viewer using Smithay's Client Toolkit
item.description: Small tutorial of using Smithay's Client Toolkit by example, building a small image viewer as a Wayland client.
item.dc:creator: Victor Berger

item.title: Entity-Component-System architecture for UI in Rust
item.description: For a fun project, Iâ€™ve been tinkering with xi-win, an experimental Windows front-end for xi-editor, written in Rust. Iâ€™m basically optimizing for performance, so making a number of somewhat unusual decisions. Among other things, Iâ€™m writing the UI myself, rather than using an existing toolkit or framework.
item.dc:creator: Raph Levien

item.title: sudo_pair - Plugin for sudo that requires another human to approve and monitor privileged sudo sessions
item.description: sudo is used by engineers daily to run commands as privileged users. But on some sensitive systems, you really want to ensure that no individual can act entirely autonomously. At Square, this includes applications that manage our internal access-control systems, store accounting ledgers, or even move around real money. This plugin allows us to ensure that no user can act entirely on their own authority within these systems.
item.dc:creator: Square

item.title: Filtering Duplicate Log Entries via Rust and Runiq
item.description: Whilst sort -u is super easy to use, the requirement of sorting your data cannot be overlooked as it means your entire file needs to be buffered into memory at once. This is not always possible, or even if possible it's not always desired. On the other hand uniq is great, but in order to sort your data in advance you still have the same issue. It was due to this that I wrote runiq, which is essentially an optimized and more flexible implementation of both of the aforemention tools for the purposes of duplicate filtering. It performs much faster, with much less memory, and does not require sorted input (although it can optimize this case).
item.dc:creator: Isaac Whitfield

item.title: My Compound Passphrase List Safety Checker
item.description: Iâ€™ve been thinking about information theory, entropy, and passphrases for a couple of months now. Iâ€™ve been particularly interested in using random passphrases as passwords. An example of one of these passphrases would be â€œstamina turret backlands rubyâ€. The words have to be as purely random as possible â€“ using your four dogsâ€™ names is not nearly as strong as a password, as an attacker would likely guess that relatively early.
item.dc:creator: Sam Schlinkert

item.title: Introducing seiri â€” a music ðŸŽ¶ manager for lots of music
item.description: TL;DR seiri is a lightweight music manager written (mostly) in Rust that helps keep huge music libraries organized. Try it today at chyyran.moe/seiri.
item.dc:creator: Ronny Chan

item.title: kanban-app - Kanban board built with Rust and Elm without Electron
item.description: This is a web-based Kanban board application, built with Elm and Rust. The only different from this application and hundred thousands of web-based application out there is: We don't need Electron!. Instead, it use native WebView (WebKit for Linux/macOS, and MSHTML on Windows),
item.dc:creator: Huy Tr.

item.title: Servo engines written in Rust deliver memory safety and multithreading
item.description: In 2012, Mozilla started the Servo project, a community effort to create new open source browser components that can take advantage of multicore hardware to improve speed, stability and responsiveness. Servo is comparable to WebKit, an open source browser engine that is the foundation of Appleâ€™s Safari browser. (Other browser engines include Blink, EdgeHTML, and Gecko.) The difference is that Servo is written in the Rust programming language, bringing lightning-fast performance and memory safety to browser internals. Rust code can drastically cut down the number of critical bugs that affect browser engines. Servo uses a modular architecture and currently runs on Linux, macOS, Windows, and Android operating systems.
item.dc:creator: Mozilla Research

item.title: bat - print code to the terminal with syntax highlighting and git integration
item.description: bat supports syntax highlighting for a large number of programming and markup languages. bat also communicates with git to show modifications with respect to the index (see left side bar).
item.dc:creator: David Peter

item.title: Hammond: A Podcast Client for the GNOME Desktop
item.description: Hammond has been in development since Sep 2017. It makes use of the Rust bindings to GNOME libraries as well as diesel, serde, reqwest, and a number other crates to build a beautiful, native application that feels right at home on the GNOME desktop.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Petridis

item.title: JARVIS - Notes on Rust Crates From Writing an RSS Reader
item.description: Way back in the dim mists of history (back in university) I wrote myself a custom RSS reader in Java and called it JARVIS1. You see, I read a lot of webcomics. Like, a lot. Some webcomics provide RSS feeds, but some donâ€™t, and as my collection grew it started to become a hassle to use Firefoxâ€™s live bookmarks to manage it all. Ultimately, I wrote up a quick Swing GUI to use as a single interface for keeping up with blogs and tracking which comics had published updates since the last time Iâ€™d checked2.
item.dc:creator: Brook Heisler

item.title: Pijul 0.10
item.description: Iâ€™m pleased to announce the new release of Pijul, version 0.10. Pijul is an easy to use, distributed and fast version control system. This release has been a long time coming, but brings in an important number of new features and stability enhancements.
item.dc:creator: Pijul

item.title: fastmod - A fast partial replacement for the codemod tool
item.description: fastmod is a fast partial replacement for codemod. Like codemod, it is a tool to assist you with large-scale codebase refactors, and it supports most of codemod's options. fastmod's major philosophical difference from codemod is that it is focused on improving the use case "I want to use interactive mode to make sure my regex is correct, and then I want to apply the regex everywhere". For this use case, it offers much better performance than codemod
item.dc:creator: Facebook Incubator

item.title: Announcing cargo src (beta)
item.description: cargo src is a new tool for exploring your Rust code. It is a cargo plugin which runs locally and lets you navigate your project in a web browser. It has syntax highlighting, jump to definition, type on hover, semantic search, find uses, find impls, and more.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cameron

item.title: dust - A more intuitive version of du in Rust
item.description: Dust is meant to give you an instant overview of which directories are using disk space without requiring sort or head. Dust will print a maximum of 1 'Did not have permissions message'. Dust will list the 15 biggest sub directories or files and will smartly recurse down the tree to find the larger ones. There is no need for a '-d' flag or a '-h' flag. The largest sub directory will have its size shown in red
item.dc:creator: andy boot

item.title: angle-grinder - Slice and dice log files on the command line
item.description:
Angle-grinder allows you to parse, aggregate, sum, average, percentile, and sort your data. You can see it, live-updating, in your terminal. Angle grinder is designed for when, for whatever reason, you don't have your data in graphite/honeycomb/kibana/sumologic/splunk/etc. but still want to be able to do sophisticated analytics.
Angle grinder can process about a million rows per second, so it's usable for fairly meaty aggregation. The results will live update in your terminal as data is processed. Angle grinder is a bare bones functional programming language coupled with a pretty terminal UI.
item.dc:creator: Russell Cohen

item.title: Faster Bulletproofs with Ristretto & AVX2
item.description:
A few months ago, BÃ¼nz, Bootle, Boneh, Poelstra, Wuille, and Maxwell published Bulletproofs, which dramatically improves proof performance both in terms of proof size and verification time. In addition, it allows proving a much wider class of statements than just range proofs.
At Chain, we (Henry de Valence, Cathie Yun and Oleg Andreev) have been working on a pure-Rust Bulletproofs implementation, whose initial version we are publishing today, together with a set of notes.
item.dc:creator: Chain

item.title: Sequoia-PGP - a modular OpenPGP implementation
item.description: Sequoia is a modular OpenPGP implementation in Rust.
item.dc:creator: pâ‰¡p foundation
